div.p: 1. IV:15. Wednesday

Walked over the Hill in the road opened to Charles’s House, and which is now continued till it comes out at the Western end of Mr Lunt’s House.— 12 minutes walk—about 3 quarters of a Mile— From 7 to 8 I walked with Charles to Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf, and bathed and swam about 5 minutes—but the effect of those two baths has been to bring out a prickly heat upon my arm and leg, as I have experienced heretofore— It was one of the roasting days, but before Noon, I went to the Quincy Stone bank, made a deposit there of the Bills paid me yesterday by Alpheus Spear and 70 dollars more of United States Bank Bills which Mr Bartlett the Cashier took in special deposit— The rest of the day I kept house, and despatched a Letter to W. W. Seaton, with the slips from 6 to 10. from the National Intelligencer for the pamphlet publication of my Speech— I revised also the four remaining slips— Ezra Dyer, brought me the copy of the Document upon which Philip Thayer obtained his pension— I promised him to write to the Commissioner of Pensions, concerning the claim of Mrs Lydia Thayer, and told him that if he would call in about a fortnight again, I should then probably have an answer from Mr Edwards— Some desultory reading—Lockhart’s life of Walter Scott.
2. IV. Thursday
Hingham— Cohasset— Perch fishing— Tranquility Grove.

With Charles in his Gig to Hingham 16 minutes to Bent’s point Bridge. 16. minutes to the next Bridge and Toll-house— 16 minutes to Mr Loring’s House at Hingham— There at 7. A.M found Revd. Charles Brooks— He went with my Son, and I with Mr Loring to Cohasset for a fishing party— There were no boats ready— Found at the House at Cohasset, Mrs Nichols the blind old Lady of 82, who reminded me of my visit to her, on the 3d. of August last year— I had forgotten the day, but she remembered it because it was her birth-day— She said she had lived with seven generations of the human family—distinctly remembering her great-grandfather who died at the age of 94, when she was 6 years of age— Then her grandfather and father—her children grand children, and great grandchildren; of whom she has 8; all born since she became blind—nine years since.— She prides herself much upon her age, and is quite intelligent, and cheerful— They took me on to the further beach, where I went out in a row-boat, exchanged on the water for another— I had three companions, all unknown to me; but whose names I learnt by their discourse with one another— MrLincoln, Mr Barnes, and Dr Foster— We fished between 2 and 3 hours, changing four or five times our position, caught each about one dozen white and read perch—and only one mackerel—landed soon after noon and returned to the Nichols house to dine upon chowder
chowder— The party at dinner consisted of more than twenty persons, several of whom I did not know, or did not recognize— Among them were Mr Richardson the Minister, my predecessor in Congress, J. C. Doane of Cohasset, Solomon, Jotham and Jairus Lincoln, Peleg Sprague,Gould formerly teacher of the Latin School in Boston and others— We dined temperately at 2. and after a couple of idle hours returned to Hingham— On our way stopp’d at the Old Colony House and saw my old fellow-student and friend Benjamin Pickman, now 75 years of age—almost a wreck— He has lost his wife and Son—his daughters have married and departed from him—he has left Salem, and now lives with his Son’s widow in Boston— He says he was now driven by the heat of the Season from Boston, where he feared it would wholly break him down, and took lodgings at the Old Colony House, not being able to find any at a private House— He is so deaf that he finds it difficult to hold conversation, but says that he has more comfort of life residing in Boston with his Son’s widow, than he could have had in his solitude at Salem, or indeed any where in this world. I returned with Mr Loring to his house, and thence at 6. O’Clock went with him to Tranquility grove, where was an assemblage chiefly of Ladies at a Pic-Nic Tea-party.— Mr Loring had told me this morning that there would probably be as many as 500 Ladies there— That he had told them they must not expect a Speech from me; but he hoped that when he should introduce me to the company, I would make a few remarks— I have a natural antipathy and utter unfitness for extemporaneous public Speaking, without a topic, or with so worthless a topic as myself— And often as I have been called to do it, every time of going through the operation is more irksome to me than the last before— All the pleasure of my fishing party was poisoned by the anticipation of the awkward figure I should make by speechifying to the Ladies, upon public affairs.— But what was my amazement and confusion when upon reaching the spot where they were assembled, Mr Loring introduced me as the Representative of the District in Congress; took from his pocket a written Speech of about ten minutes length loaded with the most fulsom adulation which he read in a tone of animated Oratory— Instead of sinking into the ground overwhelmed with shame, I had the utmost difficulty to refrain from bursting into a fit of laughter— But preserved the most immovable gravity of face, and answered by a helter skelter address to the Ladies, of about five minutes in duration— The merit of brevity served as a substitute for all other and it passed off without sign of displeasure, and without mortifying apology— Tea and Coffee and Cakes were then served round, and a song as sickening as the written speech of Mr Loring, was read by the Revd. Mr Brooks, with much animation, and sung by several Ladies and Gentlemen— Other songs followed, and it was near 8 O’Clock when, my family, who had come over this afternoon from Quincy, retired— My wife—Louisa C. Smith—Mary and Charles’s wife had all come over— I returned, where I saw for a few minutes Mr Edward Thaxter— I condoled with him on the decease of his wife who has died since I saw her this time last year— I rode home with Charles, and alighted at my door, just before the Evening bell at nine—
3. IV:15 Friday

Walk to Charles’s House, and saw the Sun rise from its South-eastern corner— Precisely 200 paces from my gate to his— Visit to my garden of gigantic weeds—called in by Mrs Mary Jane Laurence widow of a Soldier of the last War with England— She has received according to the Law a Pension for five years, and wishes to have it continued— This however I have not been able to obtain.— She has also a warrant for a quarter Section of Land in Missouri, which she supposes has been sold for the payment of taxes, and which she would be glad to have redeemed for the benefit of her Son, to whom the title of the father, subject to her right of dower descended— She has applied to Dr Shurtleff, who has a land agent in Missouri, and gave her some information concerning the condition of the Land. I advised her to apply to him again to ascertain whether it has been sold and is yet redeemable; but promised if she desired it to take the warrant with me to Washington next winter, and there ascertain whether it can yet be made available to her Son and herself— Mr William Hiester a member of the last and preceding Congress was here with his Son, and another Pennsylvanian whom I think he called Dr Shepherd, travelling for amusement and curiosity— My Son went to Boston and returned to dinner— I went over to his house towards Evening but found him suffering with a head ache to which he is occasionally subject— In the Evening I called into visit my next door neighbour George W. Beale, who was at the Bank but soon returned— Met there F. A. Whitney and his Sister.
4. IV:30. Saturday

After breakfast I walked over to Charles’s house, and found him recovered from his indisposition of yesterday— Morning visit from Mr Bradley Miner, of Neponset village who keeps the school in the House on this side the Bridge, and preaches to a small congregation of Baptists on the other side. With him was a Mr Pendleton of New-Bedford— Their conversation was about the late Session of Congress, and Texas and abolition of Slavery. Mr Pendleton made enquiries concerning the votes of members of the House from Rhode-Island— Mr Pendleton spoke much also of the Cilley duel, and the proceedings of the House concerning it— The Ladies went over to Weymouth this afternoon, and Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— I despatched a Letter to the Commissioner of Pensions concerning the claim of Mrs Lydia Thayer— Kept house for the warmth of the weather, but great part of the day was absorbed in reviewing documents respecting our relations with Mexico and Texas— I am writing an Appendix for the pamphlet publication of my Speech— Joseph H. Adams was here and dined with us.
5. IV:15 Sunday

Twenty-nine years this day since we sailed from Charlestown in the Ship Horace for St. Petersburg; and what an eventful series of years has since that time passed away. Communion day— Mr Lunt’s morning Sermon was from 1. Corinthians 10.16. “The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? the bread which we break, is it not the communion of the body of Christ?” The doctrine was that the Christian dispensation instituted a new and distinct community, selected from all the Nations of the Earth, and bound together by the ties of one common faith—one Lord, one baptism, and that in its ultimate result all tyranny and oppression, War and Slavery must vanish from the face of the Earth— The communion was administered jointly by Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt— The afternoon discourse was from Revelation 11.17—“We give thee thanks, O Lord God Almighty, which art, and wast, and art to come—on the eternity of God”— The Quincy family were Meeting in the Morning, and the men in the afternoon—all in deep mourning; Mrs Sarah Miller, mother of Mrs Quincy junior having died last week— President Quincy walked home with me this afternoon, and made enquiries if I could furnish him, information of the Boylston family, as connected with Harvard-College— I could give him but little— Mr Quincy has ready for the Press a History of the College, which he publishes as an appendage to his Discourse delivered at the second Centennial Anniversary of its foundation— He promised to send me a copy of the new Regulations adopted by the Government of the University modifying the course of studies of the Undergraduates— I read the first Sermon of the 11th. Volume of Saurin—the first of a series upon the Passion of Jesus Christ— Paid an Evening visit to Mr Thomas Greenleaf— Only he and his wife were there— Both their daughters are married— Mary Ann to Dr Woodward since I went from home last August— Their Son Price was at Our house— Sprinkling of rain this Evening, but not enough to moisten the surface of the Earth— Much occupied upon the Supplement of my Speech
6. IV. Monday.

Mr Ebenezer Adams called by appointment at 9. this morning; and Deacon Spear— Charles and I went with them and viewed the ground staked out upon my Baxter Woodlot for the new road from the granite Bridge to Randolph— It cuts up my lot and takes from it not only land for the road, but a strip fit for nothing, and running the whole length of the road— We returned by the new roads to Willard’s ledge and the Captain’s Bridge— The morning was excessively sultry; but as we were returning the wind veered easterly and it became cool— There was afterwards a copious thunder shower— Two men from Braintree, by the name of Randall and Penniman came to make enquiries concerning Widow Pension claims, Randall, for his mother in Law Betsey widow of Heman Sturdivant, and Penniman for Lydia, Widow of Abraham Thayer.— They are labouring under some difficulties to prove the specific services of the deceased husbands— The regiments, companies and Officers under whose command they served— I gave them a copy of the pamphlet collection of the Pension laws and Executive Regulations, and referred them to the recent Act of 7 July 1838 and the Regulations of the Secretary of War, for its execution.— I advised them to get prepared the Declarations of the Claimant Widows required by the Regulations, and such of the prescribed Testimony as they could procure, and told them if they would bring those documents to me, I would forward
forward them to the Commissioner of Pensions with a recommendation— A Mr C. J. M’Reading, a Methodist Minister and Agent for the American Bible Society was here this afternoon; travelling to collect contributions; for the Society— He intimated a wish to call a meeting of the Congregational Society at the Stone Meeting House, and to address them, to raise a collection, and a desire that I would promote the cause by my recommendation and influence— I advised him to consult the Ministers Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt, as to the probable success of calling a Meeting to take up a collection, which I observed the People of the town and parish might not relish— I said Mr Lunt had yesterday notified the auditory that a collection for a parish Library would be taken up next Sunday, and that a too frequent renewal of those calls might be not acceptable— But that being here only a part of the year, and recently returned from an absence of eleven Months, I could not so well judge of the dispositions of the People; of which the Ministers could better inform him— Charles and his wife spent the Evening.— I finished the Supplement to my Speech, and wrote to Seaton— The Secretary at War, has dismissed Dr Mayo, from a clerkship in the Department, for having communicated to me a copy of President Jackson’s Letter to William S. Fulton, Secretary of the Territory of Arkansas of 10 December 1830.
7. IV.15. Tuesday.

I received a Letter from Joseph Gales junr. with information that he had received my Letter of 31. July, with the preface for my pamphlet Speech, addressed to W. W. Seaton— That he had left Washington, a day or two after I did, and was gone to Canada— But that he had given my preface to the compositor— I changed therefore the direction of my Letter of this day, from Seaton to Gales, and despatched it with the Supplement, and the last 4 Slips of the Intelligencer.— Squire Lemuel Humphrey of Weymouth, came with enquiries concerning a Pension claim of Mrs Tirzah Hunt; now the widow of Ebenezer Hunt a Soldier of the Revolution, and heretofore widow of another Revolutionary War, nor named Joshua Bates— The first husband died in 1804. The second in 1827. The curious question is whether she being the widow of two revolutionary Soldiers, is entitled to the Pension which she would have obtained had she been married to only one of them— I was unable to answer the enquiries of Mr Humphrey, but gave him what information I could— Ezra Dyer was here again, about the claim of Lydia, widow of Philip Thayer.— He said that Mr Sherman Leland the judge of Probate for this County was coming out to-morrow to take for Mr Penniman the declaration of Mrs. Thayer his mother in Law— And he wished my advice whether he should avail himself of the same occasion to have the declaration of his mother in Law made;—which he could now do at half price— That he had paid Mr Leland 13 dollars for taking Mrs Thayer’s former declaration, and had got nothing for it, which he did not like— I said that Declaration might perhaps now be sufficient, and I would advise him to wait for an answer from Mr Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions, to the Letter that I had written him on this case, before incurring the expense of taking another Declaration— So he said he would do. He said he would make me compensation; but I told him I should not accept any— Towards Evening a young boy named William Wood, son of Mark Wood came with papers of a pension claim for Suzanna, widow of William Wood
Wood;—the Declaration made by her was taken in Hillsborough County, New-Hampshire 7. Novr 1837—but which have never been sent on to Washington— I promised to write to the Commissioner of Pensions, and send them to him myself— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— I began a Letter to my Constituents the Inhabitants of the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts—
8. IV:30. Wednesday.

Morning visit from Mr Lunt with whom I had a long and desultory Conversation upon topics of literature and politics— I gave him copies of my Oration at Quincy on the 4th. of July 1831. of my Eulogy on James Monroe, of my second Report upon the manufactures, and of the Speech on the distribution of Rations, of 25 May 1836—and lent him the first Volume of J. B. Rousseau, which he wished to see for the Sacred Odes— My Chest of Books arrived from Washington, but I have mislaid the key— I devoted the morning to the draught of a Letter to my Constituents, but my progress with it is excessively slow.— Charles, his wife and Son John Quincy dined with us, and after dinner I took a ride with him to Hough’s Neck, and Germantown, returning round by the new Methodist Meeting House, and the Weymouth and Braintree Turnpike— He left me at the door of Mrs Anne Adams who is confined to her chamber, greatly reduced and emaciated; broken-hearted by the death of her eldest Son, Lieutt. Thomas Boylston Adams, who died in Florida last December— She has never been well since she received the intelligence of his death— He was a most exemplary Son; as she was almost an idolizing mother— Her Sister Mrs Stebbins, her daughter Elizabeth, and her Son, the passed Midshipman are with her— She was sitting up, but not well as she had been two or three days before— From thence I went to Mr Edward Miller’s where I found his Mother Mrs Charles Miller, whom I knew 51 year ago as Hannah Smith at Newbury-Port— I had not seen her for several years, and she is within a year or two of my own age— Mr and Mrs Miller soon after came in with Mr and Mrs Spooner, the latter of whom is her Sister, and two or three others visitors from Boston— It was near nine when I came home. Northern Light.
9. IV. Thursday.

I am still much pressed and oppressed for want of Time— Several hours of this morning for want of Time were wasted in search for the key of the Chest of Books and papers which I sent round from Washington, without finding it— My Letter to my Constituents too bears heavily upon my brain— The subject as usual grows upon me as I write—my progress in it is vexatiously slow, and I fear the reproach and the danger of garrulity— Mrs Frothingham, with her Son Thomas, and Mrs Edward Everett were here this forenoon, and dined with their Sister on the hill.— I paid an evening visit to Mr Daniel Greenleaf, but was warned home by a sprinkling rain, insufficient to say the drought which consumes all vegetation but that of weeds and Philadelphia Maples— I received a curious Letter from an episcopal Clergyman, named David R Gillmer who says he in controversy with infidels, who aver that all the Presidents of the United States have been of their side— And he sends me a declaration, with a request that I would sign it in
in the following words— “I do hereby declare that I never disbelieved in the truth of the Christian Religion: nor in the inspiration of the Holy Scriptures”— This is I believe the Man, whose indiscretion involved him in controversy with Gerrit Smith and Carter Braxton about the emancipation of certain Slaves— Correspondence with him must be cautious—
10. IV: Friday.

I spent a couple of hours this morning in my Garden and Nursery for exercise— The Nursery has almost become a forest of young trees raised from the seed; which have now become so large that there is no room left for more— But hundreds upon hundreds have perished, and every year I lose favourite trees, which affects me, almost as if it were the loss of friends. I had a morning visit from my aged and once intimate friend Benjamin Pickman—not more than three years my Senior, but broken down with years—his hearing gone— His voice turned to childish treble, and with an unsteady gait, but a still warm, benevolent and affectionate heart— He said there were two Ladies with him, who had stop’d at French’s tavern, to visit my father’s Monument— Joseph H. Adams was here; and George Torrey of Plymouth, a Soldier in St. Clair’s army from 1791 to 1794— He came to enquire of the prospects for the extension of the benefits of the pension Laws to that class of our National warriors— I told him I hoped it was good for the next Session of Congress— He said that he had lost his discharge after the service of three years for which he had enlisted, and that the Captain under whom he served was dead; but that Dr Hayward of Plymouth knew that he had served, and there was yet living a man who had served in the same company with him— I advised him to have the depositions of that man, and of Dr. Hayward, attesting his service, taken before the judge of probate for the County of Plymouth, to serve him in the probable event of an act of Congress extending the benefit of the Pension Laws to the warriors against the Indians from the Peace of 1783 to the Treaty of Greenville in 1794.— He said he had not been present either at the defeat of St. Clair, or at the victory of Wayne, and had been discharged before the Treaty of Greenville— I had the lock of my chest forced to get at my books and papers—but after all without finding what I most wanted, the list of persons to whom I send public documents.
11. III:45. Saturday

I called this morning at the Office of the Quincy Patriot, and took the Paper of the 19th. of August 1837. wanting to complete my file of the first year— I told Mr Greene that I proposed to publish in the next Saturday’s paper a Letter to my Constituents, which might occupy four or five of his columns, and he promised to reserve them for the purpose— I told him I would furnish the manuscript by Monday or Tuesday—and would wish to revise the proofs before the issuing of the paper— I met there a man who spoke of a house lot in Boston adjoining
adjoining the Boylston Estate near the market— He said it belonged to his Mother who proposed to sell it—and thought it would greatly increase the value of the Boylston Estate— I referred him to Mr Nathaniel Curtis— Returning home I stopp’d at Charles’s House— His children dined with us, and he and his wife passed the Evening here.— Elizabeth C. Adams took tea here; the first time she has been able to leave her mother since we arrived— She went home with her brother Joseph H, who came for her— I found the key of my chest, for which I had wasted so many hours of fruitless search— It was hanging on a brass hook, in full sight in my chamber, where I had hung it on the day of my arrival, but which had totally escaped my memory— My Letter to my Constituents and my Diary still chain me to my desk and chair.
12. III:45. Sunday.

Mr Nathaniel Hall of Dorchester, preached this morning, from James 4.14—“For what is your Life?”—out of which he made a very ingenious discourse, though not as it appeared to me much adapted to the argument in which the Apostle applies this question—which is, never for a moment to lose sight of the uncertainty of life, or of the duty connected with it of prayer to God for its continuance and for the ability to perform our engagements— An excellent moral principle; worthy of all acceptation and practice— There is not Life enough in his delivery— He dined with us once the last year or year before, but I did not now recollect or know him— He now dined with Charles. His afternoon Sermon was from Psalm 68.6. “God sitteth the solitary in families”— The verb sitteth has here an active or transitive sense— Thomson’s translation is “God settleth the lonely in a family.” Mr Hall has been lately married, and his Sermon was a very good exposition of the duties of the members of a family to each other—but his elocution was yet cold and lifeless— I read the second Sermon of the 11th. Volume of Saurin, upon the sentence of condemnation pronounced by Jesus Christ upon Judas Iscariot—“It would have been better for that man if he had never been born.” He says Judas is the only individual of all mankind of whom this can be positively said— This is an approach to Universalism— He says also that there are degrees of punishment and of torment in Hell— All insupportable, but some more aggravated than others— For which opinion there is, I think no warrant in Scripture.— I brought my Letter to my Constituents nearly to a close; and at the dusk of Evening visited Mr Peter Whitney— After which I attended at a Concert of sacred Music, given by the Quincy Union singing Society at the Town Hall for the benefit of Joseph Bass, an infirm old man said to be in the 88th. year of his age— There were 25 male singers, and 8 or 9 girls.— Two fiddles; one Base Viol one Violoncello, one flute and one Trombone— The Capel meister or leader of the band was Mr Tirrell the wheelwright, whose only personal performance was the song “There’s nothing true but Heaven” sung in a weak but not unpleasant voice; and with much delicacy of taste— One very pretty girl, Sarah Fiske, daughter of the Shopkeeper, played on the Piano and sung the Solos between Chorus— She sung once also to her own playing; not a remarkably well chosen song; and with rather a husky voice— The pieces selected were generally good— The Cherubim and Seraphim of Handel— The lift up your heads ye everlasting Gates, which I once joined in performing at an exhibition at Cambridge— The closing Stanza of Old Hundred were among my most delightful of Melodies— None of these persons
persons were musicians by profession— The hall was well filled, and the most perfect order and decency was observed in the performances. They adjourned to this day three weeks— It was about 10 O’Clock when I got home
13. III:30. Monday

Clear morning— I endeavoured without success to get a glimpse at the rising dog star; but the belt of Orion, brilliant when I rose had faded out of sight before Sirius had reached the horizon— I walked over the hills and saw the rising Sun from the Southeast corner of my Son’s house— Then came home and finished my Letter to my Constituents— And Alas! this was all the business of the day— It vanished like so many others, I know not how— Mr French of Braintree came as he said on business—which was to say that he, and some others owned some Acres of Salt-marsh adjoining mine at the Mount Wollaston farm— That my tenant Alpheus Spear, frequently did them damage, by turning his Cattle out on my land where they trespassed upon theirs— They had agreed therefore to make a fence, and he proposed that we should meet on the spot to ascertain the divisions, which I agreed to do next Friday afternoon at 4. O’Clock— Mr French spoke also upon the late Session of Congress, Slavery, Abolition and Texas, upon all which topics I thought him rather cooled down since last Summer— Mr Dyer was here this afternoon— I had received this morning an answer from the Commissioner of Pensions, with the printed Regulations of the Secretary of War, for the execution of the act of 7. July 1838. containing the form of Declaration which Mrs Lydia widow of Philip Thayer must now make to obtain her Pension— Mr Dyer said she had already done this— Her Declaration was taken by Sherman Leland—the judge of probate for the County of Norfolk, who was out here and offered to take it and transmit the papers to the commissioner of Pensions— Mr Dyer therefore requested me to return to him the papers which he had left with me, and I did— I received from Mr Gales at Washington two printed sheets of my pamphlet Speech, which I revised, and despatched by the days mail back again— This afternoon I took the manuscript of my Letter to my Constituents to the Office of the Quincy Patriot, but Green was gone to Boston— Returning home I stop’d for about an hour, and marked the spot behind the North-east corner Pillar of his Portico, whence the rise and the setting of the Sun, may both be seen— Charles and his wife were part of the Evening with us— He had been to Boston, but returned to dine at home— It was his daughter Louisa Catherine’s Birth day. Seven years old.— She and her brothers John Quincy and Charles Francis dined with us— The youngest, named Henry Brooks, born the 16th. of last February has a wet nurse named Maria
14. III:45. Tuesday

Vain attempt again to see the rising of Sirius.— Walk round by the Meeting house 11 Minutes, and the corner of Mr. Lunt’s House, 15. up the hill to Charles’s, and there at the North-east corner pillar observed the rising Sun, at the South Corner of a small house on the summit of an Eastern hill.— Then came home, and wrote the journal of yesterday— Received two sheets of the pamphlet Speech which I revised, and enclosed back to Mr Gales Received also several Anti-Slavery pamphlets, and two or three for my wife, doubtless from
from Miss Sarah M. Grimké— These with George N. Briggs’s Address to his Constituents, declining a re-election to Congress, with the interval for Breakfast, and hearing my three Granddaughters read 2 chapters in the New Testament, and 2 in the Apocrypha stole away the morning hours— Mr John Briesler came to request a certificate of the marriage of his father and mother, which he wished as Evidence to obtain a pension for his mother— They were married in London while living with my father and mother; but they have no certificate of the marriage. He says there is an entry in the family Bible, by his father made some years after, and giving the date as of the first week in September 1787. and Mrs Briesler says that it was at Marylebone Church.— I gave him a certificate as by hearsay from my father and mother— This he thought would be sufficient for the Judge of Probate who held his Court here this day.— Morning visits, by Dr. T. Gray of Jamaica Plains Roxbury, and his Colleague and Son in Law, George Whitney— At Noon I went to the Post Office, and delivered the packet for Mr Gales containing the two revised sheets for the pamphlet— Then to the Office of the Quincy Patriot, where Mr Greene was just leaving it to go to dinner, but returned to it with me— He said he would have it ready for my revisal by Friday Morning— Mr Rowley a Varnisher of Gilt Picture frames was here all the after part of the day—dined with us, and varnished over our gilt picture frames and some of the Portraits— The varnish is a secret of his own invention— Charles also dined with us. E. Price Greenleaf was here this afternoon, and visited with me, my garden and nursery. The young trees are perishing one after the other by the drought—others stunted by insects. I went over to Charles’s House to see the Sunset, but was five minutes too late— His wife and Mary went this afternoon to Boston, and returned just before the Evening Bell— I read a few pages of Lockhart’s Life of Sir Walter Scott.
15. IV. Wednesday.

I went up the hill and from the corner pillar of Charles’s house saw the Sun rise: then retuned and shortly after let in Mr Rowley, who breakfasted with us on warm milk and water, and finished the varnishing of the picture frames and cleaning of the pictures, and returned to Boston by the Plymouth Stage, which passes by here at 10. A.M— His varnish is a secret of his own composition, and possesses as he claims a durability belonging to no other.— In his person he is a temperance Teatotaller of the most rigid sect, and made his evening meal of warm milk and water— The principal merit of his performance here was to restore the colouring in all its original brightness to the Portraits of Coll. William Stephens Smith, and of his wife, my Sister, painted by Mather Brown at London in 1786. the year of their Marriage— It seemed to me as if I was very busy all this day, but I did nothing— Only filed my Letters, and wrote one of four lines to James L. Edwards, which ought to have been written, ten days since, to enclose the papers of Widow Susanna Wood; a claimant for a pension— Charles, his wife and son John Quincy dined with us, and after dinner I took a ride with him; first to Mount Wollaston farmhouse, to see Alpheus Spear, about the fence to be made on the Saltmarsh. But his wife told us he had gone away
away this morning on a journey to be absent, four or five weeks. We then rode round a circle to Squantum, and returned about Sunset— Josiah Adams junr. with Mr Henry Gay, to enquire about the present Patent Law, and Regulations of the Patent Office— Adams thinks he has invented a machine for breaking up Tanner’s bark, for which he may hereafter apply for a Patent— But not feeling entire confidence in its success, he wished to know, if he could guard against any other persons taking out a patent for the same invention, before him— I told him I thought he might enter a caveat; but promised to look over my papers for a copy of the latest patent office-regulations— Mary and Charles’s wife spent the Evening at Mrs Lunt’s— I joined them there shortly before the Evening Bell; and soon after it, walked over the hill with Charles, and home— Read a Chapter of Lockhart’s Life of Scott; and remembered at dinner, this, as Sir Walter’s birth-day—four years after mine.
16. IV:15. Thursday.

The clouds, gathering yesterday, dispersed last evening, and the sky was clear— They rallied again this morning, and thickening, through the day, fell in moderate showers, with something of a squally gale at night.— The rain however was quite insufficient to slake the burning thirst of the Earth— I visited my garden, nursery and Orchard; the last of which is planted with potatoes, but is overrun with gigantic weeds, as I found the garden, nursery and seminary. Morning visit from Mrs Alicia Boylston, who gave me her account for the expences of nurture and education of my remaining ward, Thomas Boylston, his elder brother Ward Nicholas being now of age and just closing his course of study with Doctor Shattuck of Boston as a Physician— I gave Mrs Boylston the Letter a few days since received from Mr John Elmsley at Toronto, upper Canada, enquiring about the bequest to his mother, and requested her to put it into the hands of Mr. Curtis— Mrs Boylston, who is 75 years of age, has the appearance of scarcely passing 60. Morning visits also from Mr Minott Thayer, and a young nephew also named Thayer— Minott lent me a Letter of condolence, from my father to Coll. Ebenezer Thayer his father, upon the death of his eldest son, Elisha, half brother of Minot who died at the island of Barbadoes 1. Feby 1774— The Letter is datedApril 1774—and is one of those of which I have no copy— Mr Thayer mentioned that a Mr Wright was now lecturing in Braintree as an emissary for the Peace Society— Mr Wright, he said was an abolitionist, which Thayer himself still very earnestly disclaims to be— Mr Perkins the Orthodox Minister of the Weymouth Church has refused his pulpit for the discussion of Slavery and War— But Mr Wright Lectures and discusses elsewhere; with great ability, but much to the annoyance of Mr Thayer.— He said he thought it would be impossible to prevent the annexation of Texas—from which I conclude that this is now the Webster-whig creed— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us— I answered Mr Charles Brooks’s two Letters inviting me to attend the Meeting of the American Institute of Instruction next week at Lowell, and the Plymouth County Convention of the friends of elementary education to
to be held at Hanover, on the 3d. of next Month; declining both invitations.— The object of these meetings, is the establishment of a system of Normal Schools to qualify teachers of the common primary Schools throughout the Commonwealth.— It is an importation from Europe, to take the place of our primitive New-England system of Town Schools— It is in high favour at this present 16th. of August 1838. and may be a great benefit to the Country, but I know not what has been done, nor what is proposed to be done; and see that under a momentary glow of popularity some very difficult questions of organization, of expenditure and of Government are involved upon which I need more observation and explanation— I received also a Letter from Mr Nathaniel M. Davis of Plymouth requesting my attendance at the Hanover Convention.
17. IV:30. Friday

Cloudy morning— Clear afternoon— Planet Mercury. Evening Star. Morning visit from Mr. William Babcock, a member of the 22d. Congress from the State of New-York— Then an Antimason; but that party is now extinct in that State, as it is in this; but with this difference; that there it was not able there to accomplish its great object, as it did here; the prohibition by Law of the exceptionable Masonic Oaths— Mr Babcock is upon excursion from home for curiosity and amusement; and is passing a few days at the Old Colony House in Hingham— I took morning exercise in my garden; filled Pot with fresh Earth and planted in it sundry Apricot Stones from Washington, and 3 Plum-stones of the cherry plum from Mr T. Greenleaf’s— Of the seeds which I planted last Summer with so much care great numbers came up— Some of them in every one of the Pots, and almost every one of them has perished by exposure to the Sun, and the drought. It is melancholy to look at them— There is scarcely one seedling of the present year— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine— At 4 this afternoon I rode with Mary and Mrs Charles to the Mount Wollaston farm, and there met Mr. French of Braintree, Mr Hollis, and Mr Wilde— These with Captain Lewis Bass, Lemuel Brackett, and another Brackett, are the owners of the wide Salt-marsh plains, bordering upon my upland, because they say that my tenant Alpheus Spear turns his Cattle out, upon the marsh where they do damage— I agreed to speak to Mr William Spear to engage the fence viewers to divide the lines, that each of us might know what fencing he has to make— I then visited my mount Wollaston Orchards which has almost but not entirely failed Of the Oaks and Chesnuts of which I planted the Acorns and Nuts in 1830. there are at least 200 trees growing, and as thrifty as total neglect will allow them to be— Not I think a single walnut is left— Very few of the Apple-trees, and those barren of fruit— The Elms, set out by Kirk in the autumn of 1836. generally alive, but coming to nothing because they are cropped by Spear’s
Spear’s horses and cattle— Mr Wilde came and claimed old acquaintance He said he was about of my age, and that his father was within two years of the age of mine— And he told me with great simplicity much of his domestic history. I walked home over the hills, visiting perhaps for the last time the Merry mount itself— Dr Holbrook, and Dr George Parkman had been here on a visit during my absence— I walked to Charles’s House and saw the Sunset, behind the summit of the pyramidical cone— And three quarters of an hour later, the planet Mercury; with the naked eye, and through a glass— Mr Green the publisher of the Quincy Patriot brought me the proof sheet of my Letter to my Constituents which I revised— He came again about ten O’Clock with the remnant which I also revised and returned to him.—
18. IV. Saturday.

Saw Sirius, just as the Clock struck 4. about 10 minutes risen. It was my Son, now my only Son Charles’s birth day—now thirty-one years of age—and with what fervent prayers, and what soul-fraught benedictions does the memory of that day come over me, at each return of its anniversary.— And with what not less fervent prayers, and deep anxieties does anticipation look forward to the days so soon to come, when I shall be sleeping with my fathers, and when all the hopes of a continued good name to them and to me, will centre with him and his children— I have besides them two other Granddaughters, whose education and whose future destiny must also soon depend only upon their mother and upon him— She is a most kind and affectionate mother to them and daughter to me— May the smile and the blessing of Heaven attend them all through life, uncontaminated by the vices of the world, and cheered with the hopes of a blessed immortality— There was a man by the name of David Tirrell of Weymouth, who came to enquire of me, whether I could assist him in recovering an Estate of inheritance which he supposes has come to him by descent, in England—at a place named Thornton, but in what County he cannot tell— He has an extract from the Weymouth Town records on which are entered the birth of his Grandfather John Tirrell born in 1723 and of his father of the same name born in 1762— His own is also there dated 1789. and his great grandfathers in 1679. That is the first of the name, and all that he knows of his father is that he came from this place called Thornton— But some years since a stranger from England whose name he knows not told a relative of his in Boston, named Adams Tirrell, that there was a landed Estate in England, at Thornton, the heir to which he had heard say was an American by the name of John Tirrell— Mr Cranch of Boston has already written to London to make enquiries on the subject, and he shewed me a Letter in answer to them by a man named Maginnis dated in March last, who says there are thirty places in England named Thornton, in ten or twelve different Counties, and that without knowing which of them it is, it would be an idle and uselessly expensive search— I could give Mr David Tirrell no better comfort— Mr E. Price Greenleaf was here and spent the afternoon in my study; looking over the books in my library; and comparing the translations of Pope and Cowper, of certain passages in the 6th. Book of Homer’s Iliad
Iliad— We visited also my garden and Nursery where my seedling trees are passing through the ordeal of a severe drought, and almost unexampled Sunshine; fatal to four of them out of five— I filled Pot 2. with fresh earth and buried in it 8 Apricot Stones from Washington— Mary’s daughter Mary-Louisa, and Charles’s Louisa Catherine had changed homes—but the latter had been this day or two unwell and returned this morning to her father’s house; and Mary-Louisa here Fanny too is drooping in health and takes Calomel— Octave and Edward Frothingham were here this afternoon—and Charles and his wife this Evening.
19. IV. Sunday.

Saw Sirius again about 5 minutes risen, and afterwards marked his southing from the Southeast corner of Charles’s House— He rises there nearly behind the Stone Meeting house— Strolled over the House to the Red wedge and Russet and White wedge Apple trees, and returning saw the Sun rise on the hillock South of Strawberry hill— Heard Mr Frederic Augustus Whitney— Morning text— Matthew 20.27. [“]And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your Servant.” The preacher is the second son of the Pastor of the Church Mr Peter Whitney, and has only within a few weeks begun to preach— I was on the whole pleased with his discourse, though it contained a complimentary notice of my father, and the family thought another of myself, which would have been better omitted. I have as little relish for flattery as for insult, which I have sometimes received from the pulpit— This young man’s intention was no doubt to please— His doctrine was good, that true greatness consists in rendering service to others, and especially to mankind— His Sermon was well composed of good sense in good language, not brilliant but solid—his voice strong and clear—his articulation too distinct and slow, his self composure for a beginner quite sufficient. His prayers suitable, and not common place— His afternoon discourse was from Psalm 126.6— [“]He that goeth forth and weepeeth, bearing precious seed, shall doubtless come again with rejoicing, bringing his sheaves with him.” on the beneficial uses of Affliction— Both Mr Whitney’s texts were remarkably well chosen— On returning home I found Walter Hellen at our door— He is on a Summer excursion for health and amusement; came out from Boston this afternoon and returned this Evening; but promised to come and pass two or three days with us.— I read the 3d. Sermon of the 11th. Volume of Saurin, on the narrative of the Passion of Christ.— The Doctrine of Passive Obedience to wicked Sovereigns is laid down in this discourse without qualification— There are some sensible observations upon the absurd abuse of the Scriptures, by fanciful interpretations of them— There is a curious account of the antient usage of appointing master’s of a feast, see Ecclesiasticus ch: 32. whence he derives the modern sport of king making or the 12th Night after Christmas; and an awkward argument about predestination in which he almost ludicrously commands human reason to hold her tongue!— I went to Charles’s House, and saw the Sun set beautifully clear, and three quarters of an hour after the Planet Mercury both with the naked eye and through the Telescope for about ten minutes. We then walked to
walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s— My wife, Mary and Charles’s wife were there—and Mrs Luther Angier, Mrs John Angier and Mrs Stebbins. Mrs Adams is convalescent; but received us in her chamber— Charles walked home with me.—
20. IV:15. Monday.

I busied myself in the morning twilight for half an hour in filling my Seed Pots with fresh earth, and renumbering them, Seminary weeded— I had asked Deacon William Spear to call on me this morning, and he came— I spoke of my meeting last week with the proprietors of the Saltmarsh bordering on the Mount Wollaston farm, and their insisting upon having it fenced— He said there were other proprietors of the marsh adjoining me besides those named at that Meeting— That it would be useless to fence part of the ground leaving the rest unfenced, and that some of the proprietors would be unwilling to incur the expense— He promised to see and consult with them all, and he thought it would be best at all events to wait till Alpheus Spear shall return from his journey. Perhaps he would restrain his Cattle from doing damage on the Marsh, and save the trouble and expense of fencing altogether— Morning visit from Mr Lunt, of whom I made some enquiries respecting the Town Schools here of which he says there are six— He is a member of the School Committee of this Town; and at my request lent me the Abstracts of the School returns for 1836 and 1837.— The first annual Report of the Board of Education, and of the Secretary of the Board— Also an Address from the Norfolk County Committee to the People of the County dated 14. Novr 1837.— There is a new impulse for the improvement of education in the common town Schools; now in progress, upon which I have been already called to attend and address two public meetings— I have declined at this time, because I know nothing of the subject— And it is a Herculean labour from which I shrink, even to acquire the information necessary to form opinions that may be turned to useful account concerning it— Mr Gardner and Mr Thomas Coffin, both of the island of Nantucket, being on their way to Boston called this afternoon, and paid me a visit of curiosity— And I had a more unwelcome visitor in the Lumbago— I wrote two short Letters of business—one to James Gregory of Marblehead, from whom I received at Washington, two days before the close of the Session of Congress one of 13. pages, about the pension claims of Marblehead privateermen’s widows— I gave it to the Secretary of War, and received here a few days after my return an answer from him with a report from the Commissioner of Pensions, both of which I shall enclose to Mr Gregory— They do not comply with his urgent request, but the Secretary offers a proposal in its stead— And one to passed midshipman Francis Bartlett from whom I received also a Letter about the day of adjournment, with an enclosed application to the Secretary of the Navy for a renewal for one years of his furlough—on account of the sickness of his wife’s Sister, who lives with him— I have no acquaintance with Mr Bartlett, but he announced himself as the brother in Law of Joseph E. Sprague of Salem, and of course a Son of Bailey Bartlett of Haverhill, and he asked my influence to obtain him his furlough— I intended to have given his application to the Secretary of the Navy; but put the Letter on file, and it slipped from my memorary till last week I received a second Letter from the passed Midshipman reminding me of it, and enquiring what had been done about it— I now
I now return the application with an apology for my forgetfulness— But how can I apologize for it to myself?— Tea, and spent the Evening at Charles’s house— My temptations to the garden, seem to be resuming their power.
21. IV:30. Tuesday.

Dusk of the morning twilight occupied in assorting my seedling pots— Took off four Apples from the dwarf tree, which bears full this year; but the great proportion of Apples on all the trees are worm eaten— My English white Oak trees, bear this year many acorns— Will they ripen? After breakfast I visited again my Orchard, and was called from it, by Mr William C. Bond, who came to make enquiries respecting the present state of the science of magnetism— Not animal magnetism—now the prevailing fashion of mystification; but the polaric magnetism, scarcely less wonderful, but more unquestionable— Mr Bond has been appointed by the Secretary of the Navy with a Salary of 1500 dollars a year to make Astronomical observations, in connection with the exploring expedition, and under Instructions from Lieutenant Charles Wilkes the Commander of that expedition— He shewed me his Letter of appointment and Instructions— In which the observations on the variation and dip of the magnetic needle, are additional to the astronomical observations directed by the Secretary of the Navy— I told Mr Bond of the Lectures of Dr Dwight and Dr Sherwood last Spring at Washington, and of the discoveries claimed, I fear prematurely by Dr Sherwood, particularly that of ascertaining the Latitude and Longitude of places, by the variation and dip of the Needle. I mentioned specially Dr Sherman’s claim to have been the first to magnetise a circle and the location of the magnetic poles on the Arctic and Antarctic Circles; at 23. degrees 30 minutes from the pole of the earth; and said Dr Dwight had spoken of an Article in a late number of the Edinburgh Review, on Magnetism, which he considered as the latest Scientific Dissertation on the subject— Deacon Spear was here, and said he found some of the proprietors of the marshes bordering on the Mount Wollaston farm very intent upon having a fence immediately put up, and others equally averse to it. I determined therefore to wait till the return home of Alpheus Spear, and in the Meantime requested his Son,who was here after the Deacon, not to turn the Cattle into the pasture adjoining the Marshes; and he promised they should not be turned in. Dr Holbrook came to visit Mary’s daughter Fanny, and I asked his advice about my own ailments which increase as age advances—particularly the weakness of the lungs—the change of the voice, and the phthisical cough with which I am afflicted— He prescribed drinking occasionally 4 or 5 drops of sulphuric acid in a tumbler of Water— I answered a long standing Letter from S. C. Phillips, enclosing one from Jonathan F. Worcester corresponding Secretary of the Salem Lyceum inviting me to deliver their introductory Lecture for their next Season—which I am constrained to decline.— Joseph H. Adams was also here— Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks came out from Boston, and dined with Charles. Mary and I also dined there—my wife and Louisa C. Smith came to tea— Elizabeth C. Adams and her brother Joseph spent the Evening with us there
22. III:45. Wednesday

I have a morning hour very different from that which I wasted for three weeks together in the House of Representatives— It is that of visiting my seedling trees, still suffering with extreme drought. Morning visits from Mr Capen and Mr Wines; both engaged in the present fashionable movement for this improvement of education— I received last Winter two Letters from Mr Capen; relating to a magnificent plan for the establishment of a School for 150 boys at Cohasset, at a cost of 25000 dollars to be raised by a joint Stock Company in shares to bear and interest from 3 to 6 per Cent. I thought it a wild undertaking and did not answer his Letters—but he now requested me to inspect the plans for the buildings which he said he would send to my Son’s office at Boston, in a large folio volume— He brought me a Letter of introduction, from Revd. N. L. Frothingham— Mr Wines is a professor in one of the public high Schools in Philadelphia, and brought me a Letter from John Sergeant— Stansbury the Reporter gave me a book published by this Gentleman, at the last Session of Congress— Charles and his wife, Elizabeth C and Joseph H. Adams dined with us— Price Greenleaf spent the afternoon with me, in my Library, and after Sunset we went over to Charles’s House to see the planet Mercury which we barely could with the naked eye— He is now so rapidly approaching the Sun that after to-morrow, he will no longer be visible as evening Star.— Mr. Josiah Adams jr. came this Evening with a drawing of his perpendicular bark cutter, for which he wishes first to enter a caveat at the Patent-Office, and afterwards to take out a Patent— My time was again so much absorbed by manual labour without Sequel, that I wrote only one Letter of a few lines to Thomas P. Smith corresponding Secretary of the Boston Lyceum, declining to deliver their introductory Lecture, next October— I began one, to J. Edwards, President of the theological seminary at Andover in answer to some enquiries, received from him relating to the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— Aurora Borealis
23. IV. Thursday.

The heat and drought continue— My seedling trees suffer from them and the interest that I feel in them, all but extinguished in my absence returns to exercise the morning hour— Deacon Spear was here, and gave me a list of the owners of Saltmarsh lands bordering on the Mount Wollaston farm— Lemuel Brackett is one of them, and objects to building the fence— The rest are indifferent about it, except Benjamin V. French of Braintree who insists upon the fence. All however have now agreed to wait for the return of Alpheus Spear, before doing any thing more— I despatched a dozen Letters enclosing the Quincy Patriot of last Saturday which contains my Letter to my Constituents, and Legare’s report on the Peace Society Petitions, to one member from each town in the District represented at the Convention of this day last year— I finished my Letter in answer to that of President J. Edwards with his queries concerning the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. Four of the Letters which I have written since I returned home from Washington have
have already been published in the Newspapers— This practice renders my correspondence irksome, because I never can be sure that what I write will not be published and of course I should be cautious to write nothing unfit for publication— It gives an air of constraint to my Style; and makes the writing of a Letter, a laborious task— Besides this I was nearly two hours busied this afternoon in hunting up the two Letters that I had received last winter from Mr Nahum Capen, concerning the project of establishing a School or Academy at Cohasset.— I found them at last, and collected together all the files of Letters that I have received within the last two years, and which nearly fill a chest— My practice is to file all the Letters that I receive, and the consequence is that the files encumber my trunks with trash— Two grains of wheat in two bushels of chaff— I think I do not answer upon the average more than one Letter in five that I receive, and yet in looking over my Letter-books I find in them much frivolous correspondence and a plentiful lack of mind— I was journalizing this afternoon when Charles called at the door in his four wheeled Chaise and proposed to me a ride— We went on the Dedham road to the turn East of the Milton Meetinghouse thence over the Neponset brook and returned over Milton bridge and hill— Mr Beale and his two surviving daughters, Ann and Caroline were here this Evening— I was star-gazing to no purpose.
24. IV:45. Friday

My passion for seedling trees is returning and occupies more than the morning hour— In spite of all my yearly failures and disappointments, I have several hundreds of trees; fruit and forest from 11 to 1. year old; flourishing in my garden Nursery and Seminary—and about 50 apple seedlings in 3 large wooden boxes, which ought to have been transplanted last October but were not, because I was absent— Early Ann Peaches this day first ripe—very small, but good— I planted one Stone—in Fanny’s peach table— There is a peach seedling, a Strawberry vine, and a grape vine up from the last years planting in Mary-Louisas—nothing up in either of the other tables of that row— The apple seedling of 1834 in front of my easternmost South window, grows not rapidly but well— I planted an oblique row, of black Currants crushed, from the bush at the West end of the garden, at the easternmost end of the seminary border— I was called form my garden by Josiah Adams junr, who had a draught of a Letter to Henry L. Ellsworth, the Commissioner of Patents, requesting him to enter a caveat for Adams’s invention of a perpendicular Bark cutter— I promised him to call at four O’Clock to-morrow afternoon, at the Ten-yard to see the machine itself in operation— He said his father would call for me here— Charles went to Boston and returned to his home to dinner— David Loud was here again about the Land-warrant issued to him for the military service of his son Warren Loud, in the last War with Great-Britain, the son being now deceased—and the power of Attorney which he sent me to sell the Warrant for him, and remit to him the proceeds— I searched over again all the files of my Letters received within the last two years, but found neither the power of Attorney nor the Letter with which he sent it— I was equally unsuccessful in searching for the Letter of Petty Vaughan to the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, and to which
which I am to prepare the answer— I wrote three short Letters—one to Rufus B. Laurence, Secretary to the Lowell Lyceum, declining to deliver their introductory lecture next October—one to John Elmsley, Toronto, Upper Canada, in answer to one from him, enquiring after the bequest of Ward N. Boylston to his mother and one to Joseph Gales jr. about the pamphlet morning hour debate— As the Sun descended I became weary of writing, and with my three grandchildren Fanny, Louisa Catherine and John Quincy visited the garden, and removed more than a bushel basket full, of wind fall pears and Apples— Charles, and his wife, with Mary visited Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf— There was a very heavy thundergust 30 or 40 miles west of us, but of which we had scarcely a sprinkling. After the Evening bell at 9 O’Clock the bell was soon rung again for a fire.
25. IV. Saturday.

The fire last night was of a barn at South Weymouth, struck with lightning— From the distant sound of the thunder I should not have imagined it was so near— But I was confident that soon after the heavy thunder storm of last night on our borders, we should very soon have it over our heads—which was this day realized—from 4 this afternoon till 10 this evening, there was a continual succession of copious showers and the most terrific peals of thunder which I ever witnessed— Abundance of rain, but no superfluity to satiate the parching thirst of the earth. It came on suddenly The morning was clear, and the heat of the day sultry. I planted 3. early Anne peaches in the seminary table row of my five Grand children; and a circle of Apple-seeds and Pear cores round Fanny’s table— Morning visit from President Quincy; who invited me to Commencement next Wednesday, and to Boylston prize declamations of the next Morning; which he said was a matter of duty— I thought my age and infirmities would excuse me, but felt the force of the remark— I had much conversation with him upon the educational movement now one of the agitations of the day; and especially upon the project of establishing Normal Schools for the Education of Teachers in every County of the Commonwealth. I asked him, what was to be its operation upon our Colleges, and especially upon the University at Cambridge— His answers greatly increased my doubts as to the expediency of these Normal Schools— He seemed reluctant to give his opinions freely on the subject, but he evidently entertained apprehensions similar to those which have occurred to me— He said that there were always more of the bachelor graduates perfectly competent to keep schools than could obtain schools to keep— That the school committees of all the towns were always looking out for the cheapest Article, for the schoolmaster, and he thought the normal schools would rather make it dearer.— While we were at dinner Mr Capen of Braintree came to make known to me his grievances about a fence between his land and that which was once my brothers, who sold it to me, but of which I have given the possession to his widow for her life, and intend to secure to her children after her decease— Her tenant Hayden’s Cattle, trespass upon Mr. Capen’s land, and will not make a fence, nor a ditch either of which would sufficiently bar out the cattle. I told Mr Capen that the possession and the profits of the land were in Mrs T. B. Adams; and she being much indisposed I advised him to see her son Joseph, and make some arrangement of
of the matter with him; to which he finally consented, though he thought the most proper person for settling the difficulty was the lawful owner of the land— While he was here, his brother in Law, Josiah Adams came in, and I rode with him to Mr Gay’s tan yard, where we saw Josiah Adams junrs Vertical Bark Cutter and its operation by wheel and horse power— It is apparently a great improvement upon the old usual machine, which we also saw there— The bark they use is of hemlock— We had been there but a few minutes when a thunder cloud came up, and we had barely time to reach my home, before the plentiful rain ensued— Mr Adams’s horse and chaise were put into the barn, and he waited here nearly two hours till the rain partially subsided, when he went home—while he was here, Mrs William S. Smith came in from Boston—left New-York at 6 last evening, and came with Mr and Mrs De Wint, by the way of the Stonington railroad— She left them at Boston— Mr Smith was about three months since dismissed from his place in the Land Office, and it is about a fortnight since she left Washington— There was a succession of very heavy thunder showers, and rain without intermission till between 10 and 11. at Night.
26. IV. Sunday.

Mr Newell of Cambridge preached this morning from Psalm. 139.7. [“]Whither shall I go from thy Spirit? or whither shall I fly from thy presence?” upon the omnipresence of God—a them upon which it is not difficult to expatiate, but which is not alike easy to understand— Mr Newell dined with us, and his afternoon Sermon was from Matthew 10.5. [“]These twelve Jesus sent forth and commanded them saying, Go not into the way of the Gentiles and into any city of the Samaritans enter ye not. 6. But go rather to the lost sheep of the house of Israel. 7. And as ye go, preach, saying, the kingdom of heaven is at hand— 8. Heal the sick, cleanse the lepers, raise the dead, cast out devils; freely ye have received, freely give.” Upon the nature of the commission given by Christ to his apostles— These Sermons were both edifying, but not of extraordinary power, and less efficacious to me, owing to the great distrac- of my mind, and the lamentable failure of my memory— I requested Mr Newell, if he should see President Quincy to say to him that my present intention is to go to Cambridge next Thursday the Prize Declamation and Φ.B.K. day— Mr Degrand came out from Boston; and dined, and spent the day with us— Charles and his wife here this Evening— From the morning bell at 10—till the same hour of the Evening, I could not even visit my chamber— I then read the fourth Sermon of the 11th. Volume of Saurin, upon the denial of Christ by Saint Peter—a subject the treatment of which by this Calvinist Hugenot preacher is less satisfactory than in many other cases— It is indeed no easy topic to handle by any person believing the doctrines of Christianity, and of a philosophical turn of mind— The extent and the limitation of the miraculous power, the perpetual agency of the Scriptures in both covenants, is equally beyond the reach of human reason— The Commission to the twelve Apostles when first sent forth gave them power to raise the dead— Peter had not only witnessed many of the miracles performed by Jesus, and had been one of the three witnesses of the transfiguration— He had been so self-confident of his own fidelity, as stubbornly to promise perseverance in it against the solemn
solemn warning of Jesus himself— He draws the sword and cuts off the ear of Malchus, which Jesus by a miracle immediately restores.— Yet at the trying moment, he deserts and denies his Lord and master.— No book in the world, discloses so effectively the frailties and infirmities of human nature as the Bible— Saurin comments with acuteness and ingenuity every part of the narrative.
27. III:30. Monday.

Planted 5 early Ann Peach stones in oblique row, parallel to the fence Eastern and of the seminary, just fronting the black currant seeds— The children Mary-Louisa and Georgiana Frances also planted in their row tables, each two Early Ann Peach Stones, and I planted in Pot 1. Twelve seeds all from one Office Apple— Josiah Adams junr brought his Letter to H. L. Ellsworth, Commissioner of the Patent Office, with the drawing of his Vertical Stone-cutter—asking that he would enter a caveat for the patent right. I wrote myself to Mr Ellsworth and enclosed to him these papers. My wife, with Mary, and Abby went to Boston, where Mary had a tooth drawn which has for the last fortnight tormented her with the tooth ache. They returned before dinner, all unwell, and Mary was confined the remainder of the day to her chamber. With the Quincy Stage this afternoon came out Mr and Mrs De Wint—two of their Sons and two daughters, Julia and Emily— The rest went immediately to Mrs T. B. Adams’s— After tea I walked the half hour tour round by the Stone Meeting house Mr Lunts and Charles’s houses— There was while I was walking a light sprinkle scarcely amounting to rain, but immediately afterwards came to a gentle steady rain which continued all the Evening— Charles came over, but his wife was too unwell— The last Night had been cold almost to a frost, and this morning before Sun rise Crystal clear. I visited my orchard in the forenoon, and took note of several trees— It is now planted with Potatoes, and with Ellsworth Indian Corn— I received a very grateful Letter from Mr James Gregory of Marblehead returning the Letter from the Secretary of War, and report from the Commissioner of Pensions, about the Marblehead widows which I had sent him— Also a second letter from Jacob H. Loud, for John Adlington’s Pension certificate which I cannot find— A Letter from Aaron Clark Mayor of New-York, and one from E. R. Tremane Chairman of the Lecture Committee of the Mercantile Library Association at New York, urgently pressing an invitation to deliver the introductory Lecture to their course, early in November next— I had declined performing the same service for the last winter’s Season in March 1837. on account of the state of my voice which of course grows weaker and weaker every year— I have as much as I can now do to answer these Letters— I read a Lecture on Public Instruction in Prussia, read before the American Institute, by George S. Hillard in August 1835, but written by Mrs Elizabeth Robbins—published at Philadelphia, in 1836. and given me I believe last summer by Mr Charles Brooks of Hingham— There is some account in it of the Prussian system—extracted from the report of Cousin— It states that in a population of 12,726823. in Prussia, there were 2,043,030. children between 7. and 14. at school. 13.15ths. of the whole number— The Law establishing the system was given in 1819.
28. IV. Tuesday

Fresh earth and manure to Mary-Louisa’s Seminary Northern Plantation— The transplanted Chestnut-Oak trees have fallen into the scar and yellow leaf, immediately after the rains of last Saturday; and the leaves of my garden old hickory are all spotted with yellow— Catherine and sugar pears full ripe. Mr and Mrs De Wint and their four children dined and spent the day with us— Julia and Emily remain here— Mr and Mrs De Wint and the two boys returned this Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s— A Mr Sears brought me a subscription paper for a volume to be published of legal opinions delivered by the late Chief Justice of the United States John Marshall and I subscribed for one copy. I was occupied two or three hours of this forenoon and as many after dinner in searching for the pension certificate of John Adlington, which he left with me last winter to sustain his application for an increase of his pension, and which he now wants to receive his half years pension payable the first of next month; but could not find it— This with due attention to visitors absorbed the whole day.— The multitude of Petitions with which I was charged at the last and preceding Congress, amounting to about one thousand, with the other business of the House was so distracting that in spite of every precaution to keep a special register of them of my own, and minutes of what was done with every one of them it has been impossible for me to avoid mislaying several papers, belonging to others and every one of them is now called for— Thus I lost the day without writing a single Letter, and without reading a page of Public Instruction
29. III:15. Wednesday.

Commencement day at Cambridge— Top dressing to Fanny’s Plantation, South-side of the Seminary, where is an Apple-tree, second year of its growth, and a currant bush— I had the whole row of tables enlarged, and planted a dozen Catherine Pear seeds—trimmed the Northernmost of two young Cherry trees in the Garden. I received one hundred copies of my fragment Speech, in pamphlet, from Gales and Seaton and despatched thirty of them by the Mail— Reading it to revise the press and the morning was gone— After dinner I wrote an answer to Jacob H. Loud’s two Letters about John Adlington’s Pension Certificate— I made a third long and tedious search to find his papers but in vain— I surely left them at Washington— I wrote also to A. L. Peirson President of the Salem Lyceum declining to deliver their introductory Lecture next October.— Charles and his family dined with us, and the De Wint family and Elizabeth C Adams spent the Evening here— Also Mr Peter C. Brooks junr who came out from Boston this afternoon and lodges to Night at Charless. Julia De Wint
De Wint received a note from Miss Hannah Miller, inviting her to pass the Night at her fathers house and go with them to-morrow on an excursion to Cohasset.— She went accordingly.
30. V. Thursday
To Cambridge— Prize Declamations ΦBK. Home.

At half past six this morning, I took Thomas, to drive me, with Charles’s Buggy, and one of my horses, and at eight O’Clock I was at President Quincy’s house at Cambridge and in his study— The judges of the Boylston-prize declamations dropped in one by one till 9. when we proceeded to the Meeting House, and the prize declamations commenced— There were eight competitors of the Junior Class— 14 of the Senior Class, and two of the Class yesterday graduated— One of the Juniors, one of the Seniors did not speak; and there were 22 who spoke— The rule limits each speaker to 5 minutes of time, but some of them exceeded it— The performance was over about a quarter past 11. The judges then returned to the Presidents study, and awarded the prizes— There were 11. votes—F C Gray—Charles G. Loring, Judge Merrill, Chief Justice Lemuel Shaw, Mr Walker, Minister of Charlestown, T. W. Ward, and 3. others, with President Quincy and myself— We first balloted for the two first prizes at once—but there was not a majority for any one speaker— Then the ballot was for one— The prize was taken by Samuel Elliot, a son of William Eliot deceased, and a Grandson of Alden Bradford—the brightest Star of all the Undergraduates—a Senior— The other first prize was taken by Thomas Dawes, also a Senior, in my judgment much the best speaker of the day; but not remarkable as a Scholar— He spoke Cato’s soliloquy, Elliot spoke a passage from Webster’s Eulogy on Adams and Jefferson— The three second prizes were taken by Francis Lemuel Capen a Senior, who spoke in Latin, part of the fourth Oration of Cicero against Catiline; the only Latin that was pronounced and he spoke it well— By William Ingersoll Bowditch, a graduate of the present year, a son of the late Dr Bowditch, but no heir to his labours— He had no part at the Commencement—he spoke a passage from Byron’s Marino Faliero—and by John Kebler, a German, who is of the Senior Class and spoke an admirable passage from Burke’s Reflections on the French Revolution— The speaking was all good, and so nearly equal that there was scarcely one of the performers, but had one or more votes for one of the prizes. Dawes drew an involuntary clap from the auditory; but President Quincy rose and requested that there might be no clapping.— The judges returned to the Church and the President announced the names of the successful competitors, with a remark on the general excellence of the speaking, and the nearly equal merit of all the performers— The members of the ΦB.K. society then left the Church and went to the Chapel Hall whence they walked in procession; beginning with the immediate members, Seniors and Juniors Undergraduates, and naming the classes backward beginning with the class of 1838, and calling successively the class of each preceding year to 1790. There they stopped and of several classes between that and 1800 there was no representative— Four veterans, Prentiss Mellen of 1784. Henry Ware of 1785, Alden Bradford of 1786. and myself of 1787. closed the procession, preceding Edward Everett, who as Governor of the Commonwealth took the lead of us, and was followed immediately by the Revd. Caleb Stetson the Orator, and James Cook Richmond the Poet with Professor Henry Ware junr acting as Chaplain who opened the meeting with prayer. Mr
Mr Stetson delivered an Oration against the utilitarian system of philosophy, full of wit humour and sound sense— He was about an hour and a half in the delivery, and no one thought it long— Mr Richmond’s poem was a sort of Monody upon Pokamoket or Philip Sachem of Mount Hope, who has of late become a great favourite with our historical romancers— The versification was indifferent and the poem dull, but not long.— Dined at President Quincy’s— Mrs Quincy, her two sons Josiah and Edmund—and four daughters—Elizabeth Susan, Sophia, Abigail and Anna Dr. Alexander of Baltimore, Isaac P. Davis—F. G. Gray—J. S. C. Green Abbott Lawrence, Judge Merrill, John Pickering Bayard, son of Samuel Harrison Smith, Mr Walker of Charleston, and T. W. Wood formed the company— The Ladies sent by me a basket of peaches, grapes and Nectarines to us— I paid a short visit to Dr. Waterhouse and reached home shortly before 9 in the Evening— There was a heavy thunder shower between 1 and 3 P.M. the streams from which were visible all the way home— I found the family all together, and Julia De Wint returned well pleased with her visit to Cohasset, and the Beach.
31. IV. Friday.

Mr Thomas B. Gannett junr. son of Mr Thomas B. Gannett of Cambridge, brought me a Letter of introduction from his father with a request for my recommendation of him to the Secretary of War, for a second Lieutenant’s Commission in the army.— He had a warm recommendation from Mr Richard Fletcher the member of the House of Representatives of the United States from Boston; with an additional confirmation by Governor Everett on the same sheet— To which I also added mine— I enquired of Mr Gannett what had been hitherto his profession and he said that five years since he had passed an examination, and a second one to enter the University at Cambridge but did not enter— He has since then been concerned in trade and unfortunate owing to the imprudence of his partner— This account of himself was not very encouraging as a warrant for asking a recommendation from a stranger; but it was at least not deficient in candour— We had afternoon visits from Mr Joseph Angier, and his wife, who was a Miss Roach of New-Bedford; and afterwards from Mrs Eustis the widow of the late Governor.— Towards Night I went up the hill to Charles’s house; but he and his wife spent the Evening with us— I received a Letter from Mr Lewis Tappan of New-York, asking for a copy of my fragment Speech, and permission to the Executive Committee of the American Anti-Slavery Society to print an edition of 1000 copies there.— Found and gave to Charles my old Roman coins—

Day— I sleep little in the Night, and awake often before 3. in the morning—usually soon after 3. and sometimes between 4 and 5— It takes me a full half hour, often more to wash, and dress, and then another hour to visit my seedling trees, and waste time in the Garden Nursery and Seminary— Journalize, heavily, read in the Bible with the Children or the Newspapers till 8— Breakfast— Journalize, read, or write Letters till 2. Dine—read, write, and visit my garden till Sunset. Evening with my family. [symbols]
